SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Feeling out of sorts, fatigue, and lightheadedness.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He denies fever, chills, and shortness of breath but reports occasional chest cramps and a slight cough. He has been struggling with his diet due to recent home renovations and eating out more frequently. The patient is taking his medications and monitoring his blood pressure regularly.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue and lightheadedness.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses occasional chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Endorses a slight cough.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm, 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Ejection fraction of 45%, moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Congestive heart failure.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by the physical exam findings and chest X-ray.
• Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once daily. Monitor daily weights and report any weight gain or shortness of breath. Order another echocardiogram.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is well managed at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue to record blood pressures at home and report any elevated readings through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female presenting with right knee pain. The patient reports that she was changing a light bulb on a ladder when she stumbled and twisted her knee while trying to catch her fall. The incident occurred yesterday. The pain is located on the inside of her knee. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it has not provided significant relief. 

The patient has a past medical history of atrial fibrillation and is currently taking digoxin. She has had a previous surgery for a nose job.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right knee pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Tenderness over the medial portion of the right knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain with valgus stress and knee flexion. Normal sensation in the lower extremities.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right knee: No fractures or dislocations. Good bony alignment. A small amount of fluid is present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female presenting with right knee pain after a fall.

Acute medial meniscus sprain/strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has tenderness over the medial meniscus area and pain with valgus stress and knee flexion. X-ray shows no fractures or dislocations.
• Medical Treatment: Provide a knee brace and crutches for temporary use. Recommend Motrin 800 mg every 6 hours with food for pain relief (two-week supply).
• Follow-up: Reevaluate in one week. If not improved, consider ordering an MRI.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with lower back pain. The patient reports lifting heavy boxes too quickly while helping his daughter, and experienced a popping sensation in his lower back. The pain has been persistent since the incident, which occurred on Saturday morning. The patient has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat for pain relief with minimal success. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon, but it has since resolved. The patient finds it difficult to find a comfortable position while sleeping.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower back pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic heart murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine, pain with flexion and extension of the back, negative straight leg raise.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: Elevated.

RESULTS

Lumbar spine X-ray: Normal bony alignment, no fractures noted.

Diabetes labs: Hemoglobin A1c elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with lower back pain.

Lumbar strain:
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's history and physical exam suggest a lumbar strain from lifting heavy boxes.
• Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity, and refer to physical therapy.

Diabetes type 2:
• Medical Reasoning: Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8, indicating suboptimal control of diabetes.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice a day.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

Hypertension:
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are consistently elevated.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis:
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee osteoarthritis well and no further workup is needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension, who presents for his annual exam. The patient reports a tough spring with pollen and moving his daughter to college. He has been managing his depression with Prozac and has not had any incidents recently. He has been struggling with hypertension but has been taking Norvasc regularly during the business week. He experiences shortness of breath with exertion while running 4-5 miles a day.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills, or weight loss.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath with exertion, nasal congestion from pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses occasional chest pounding during exercise.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. No extra heart sounds.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.
• Head and Neck: Pain to palpation of sinuses.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is doing well on Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill ordered.

2. Prior lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is exercising regularly and has good breathing function.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: No need for further follow-up with the surgeon.

3. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient has been taking Norvasc and has improved blood pressure control.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage patient to take medication consistently, even on weekends.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right index finger pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents with right index finger pain. The patient reports that she was skiing over the weekend and while going over moguls, her ski strap caught on her finger, causing it to bend back. The incident occurred on Sunday. She has tried applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but the pain persists. The patient experiences increased pain with movement.

Ms. Brooks also reports a history of constipation, for which she takes Miralax. She had an appendectomy at the age of 18.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right index finger pain.
• Gastrointestinal: Endorses constipation.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Tenderness over the distal phalanx of the right index finger. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS

X-ray: No fractures noted. Everything appears normal and well-aligned.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents with right index finger pain following a skiing incident.

Right index finger contusion.
• Medical Reasoning: Based on the physical examination and normal x-ray, the patient has a contusion on the tip of her right index finger.
• Medical Treatment: Provide an aluminum foam splint and prescribe Motrin 600 mg every six hours for one week.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to call and return for a follow-up if the pain does not improve within a week.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper, a 65-year-old female, presents with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient reports fatigue, feverishness with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also endorses increased anxiety and depression. She has been anemic since the age of 13 and had a hysterectomy in 1996. Her last colonoscopy was approximately 5-6 years ago with no significant findings.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• General: Fatigue, feverishness, chills.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath, wheezing.
• Neurological: Headaches.
• Psychiatric: Anxiety, depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: No apparent distress.
• Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds.
• Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended.

MEDICATIONS

• Ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets, twice daily.
• Over-the-counter vitamin B12.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Iron deficiency anemia:
• Medical Reasoning: Long-standing history of anemia, recent inability to donate blood, and low hemoglobin and ferritin levels.
• Additional Testing: Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 12 weeks.
• Medical Treatment: Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily with orange juice for improved absorption. Refer to hematologist for further evaluation and potential intravenous iron treatment.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to take iron pills with orange juice and to follow up with hematologist and for scheduled endoscopy and colonoscopy.

Anxiety and depression:
• Medical Reasoning: Patient endorses worsening anxiety and depression.
• Medical Treatment: Monitor and consider referral to a mental health professional if symptoms persist or worsen.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental discovery of pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male with no significant past medical history, who presents with worsening headaches over the past few months. He denies any history of headaches in the past. He was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for a neurosurgical consult due to the incidental discovery of a pituitary lesion during the workup for his headaches. The patient reports that the headaches are located behind his eyes and have a dull, nagging ache. The onset was gradual, starting about three months ago, and has been worsening over time. The headaches tend to be worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient denies any associated symptoms such as fever, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he has noticed that he has been bumping into door frames recently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Neurological: Endorses worsening headaches. Denies fever, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out.
• Ophthalmologic: Denies changes in vision or balance. Endorses bumping into door frames.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological: Patient is alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities.
• Ophthalmologic: Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

RESULTS

MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are noted.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male with an incidental discovery of a pituitary lesion during the workup for worsening headaches.

Pituitary adenoma.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression due to the pituitary lesion.
• Additional Testing: Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test.
• Surgical Treatment: Transsphenoidal approach for surgical excision and decompression of the pituitary fossa is indicated. The patient has been informed of the risks associated with anesthesia and surgery.
• Patient Education and Counseling: The patient has been educated about the surgical procedure and its risks. He has been advised to call if he has any questions.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal. She presents today as a new patient with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. She reports having chest pain for four days in early October 2020, which resolved on its own. The patient also experienced difficulty swallowing during that time, which has also resolved. She denies any current symptoms but is concerned that there might be an underlying issue.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills, or weight loss.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain. Endorses history of chest pain in October 2020.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain. Endorses difficulty swallowing in the past.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies joint or muscle pain.
• Neurological: Denies headaches or dizziness.
• Psychiatric: Endorses anxiety related to job transition.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: In no apparent distress.
• Neck: Supple without thyromegaly or lymphadenopathy.
• Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm.
• Gastrointestinal: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No rebound or guarding.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal. She presents today with a referral from the ER for esophagitis.

Possible etiologies:
• GERD
• Dyspepsia
• Esophagitis
• Musculoskeletal etiologies
• Anxiety

Suspect she had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, plus or minus a contribution from musculoskeletal etiologies.

Plan:
• Discussed the option of EGD versus monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change.
• Follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of kidney function. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will be starting speech therapy soon. Katherine has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The geneticist mentioned potential kidney issues associated with her syndrome.

The patient has 8-10 wet diapers per day and consumes a combination of pea protein milk, water, and diluted juice. She has a twin sister who is developing normally.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy during examination.
• Genitourinary: Normal frequency of wet diapers (8-10 per day).
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Ophthalmologic: Small appearing eyes.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of kidney function due to potential congenital anomalies associated with her chromosomal deletion syndrome.

• Medical Reasoning: Screening for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract is warranted given the patient's syndrome.
• Additional Testing: Obtain a kidney ultrasound today to assess for any abnormalities.
• Follow-up: If the kidney ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up with nephrology is needed. If abnormalities are found, the patient will be scheduled for a follow-up appointment at the town center location to discuss next steps and future management.

Patient Agreements: The patient's guardian understands and agrees with the recommended medical evaluation plan.

CC:

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HPI:

Diana is a patient who presents today with right wrist pain and swelling after a fall while doing laundry. She reports slipping on the stairs and extending her arms to catch herself, resulting in immediate pain and swelling in her right wrist. The injury occurred yesterday morning. She has not had any previous injuries to this arm. The pain is severe, rated at 9/10. She has tried ice, an ace wrap, and ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal improvement. She reports some tingling in her fingers but no numbness.

EXAM:

Examination of the right wrist shows significant swelling, bruising, and tenderness on palpation. Pain is present with flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction of the wrist. She is able to make a fist but not tightly. Bony crepitus is noted, suggesting a potential fracture.

RESULTS:

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture with evidence of dorsal angulation of the distal fracture fragment and ulnar styloid fracture.

IMPRESSION:

Right wrist Colles' fracture.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. We will proceed with the following plan:

1. Apply a brace to the right wrist for support and immobilization.
2. Schedule surgery as soon as possible to repair the fracture.
3. Prescribe Ultram 50 mg every 6 hours for pain management.
4. Begin physical therapy a few weeks after surgery to aid in recovery and strengthening of the wrist.
5. Follow up in one month to assess progress and discuss the possibility of the patient going on vacation.

The patient understands and agrees with the recommended treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient reports slipping and falling while working on his property a week ago, resulting in right knee pain. He has been taking ibuprofen for the swelling. The pain is worse with flexion and extension of the knee.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: No shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination of the right knee: Edema and effusion present.
- Palpation: Pain to palpation on the medial aspect of the right knee.
- Range of Motion: Pain on both flexion and extension of the knee.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the right knee: No fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee pain (MCL strain).
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice a day for pain and swelling.
- Supportive Care: Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times a day.
- Activity Modification: Advise the patient to elevate the leg, stay off the leg, and avoid yard work for a couple of weeks.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg.
- Lifestyle Modification: Refer the patient to a nutritionist for dietary counseling to help manage hypertension and potentially reduce the need for medication.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a middle-aged male who presents today with left shoulder pain that he has been experiencing for approximately three weeks. He cannot recall any specific injury but has been active and working on renovating his basement. He has had occasional aches and pains in the past, but nothing that Tylenol couldn't alleviate. The pain is constant and worsens with pressure or reaching for objects. He has been taking two extra strength Tylenol every six to eight hours, which helps but does not completely alleviate the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his arms or hands.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Reviewed, within normal limits.

Left shoulder: Limited active and passive range of motion, tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus, no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints.

Neurovascular exam of the left arm: Capillary refill less than three seconds, sensation intact to light touch.

Hand grips: Good.

RESULTS

Left shoulder X-ray: No fractures.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

1. Order an MRI for the left shoulder to further evaluate the cause of pain.
2. Refer the patient to physical therapy for 6-8 weeks.
3. Continue taking Tylenol as needed for pain relief.
4. If symptoms do not improve, consider a steroid injection for the shoulder.
5. Provide educational materials on physical therapy and what to expect.
6. Schedule a follow-up visit after completion of physical therapy.

INSTRUCTIONS

- Attend physical therapy sessions as scheduled.
- Continue taking Tylenol as needed for pain relief.
- Follow up with the doctor after completing physical therapy or sooner if symptoms worsen.
- Call with any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a patient who presents with occasional left knee pain. The pain occurs less than once a day while walking, causing her knee to feel unstable and as if it might give out. She reports that the pain passes quickly and does not last long. She denies any history of injury to the knee or any popping sensation. The patient has not taken any pain medication for this issue, as the pain does not last long. She is concerned about participating in line dancing during an upcoming trip due to her knee pain.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses left knee pain and instability.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
• Endocrine: Reports slightly elevated fasting blood sugars around 130.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. Appreciates a slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.
• Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam reveals no ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 122/70
• Pulse: 72
• Respirations: 16
• Temperature: 98.2

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left knee pain: Suspect arthritis. Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen muscles around the knee.
2. Hypertension: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Diabetes mellitus: Order hemoglobin A1c to assess the need for adjustments to metformin dosage. Also, order a lipid panel.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy for stage three non-small cell lung cancer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Beverly is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She presents for follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, and biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending at this time. The patient reports minimal cough and sore throat today. She has been experiencing fatigue and a dry cough but denies shortness of breath, nausea, or vomiting. She has been eating less than usual but does not feel like anything is getting stuck when swallowing.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Stage three non-small cell lung cancer.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: WNL
Temperature: WNL
Heart Rate: WNL
Oxygen Saturation: WNL

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Crackles in lungs bilaterally.
Skin: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side, possibly related to radiation.
Lower extremities: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lung cancer.
- Continue with the current regimen of cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy and current dose of radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of radiation to assess tumor size for potential surgical removal.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to help reduce inflammation and improve cough and shortness of breath.

3. Painful swallowing.
- Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to help with swallowing and prevent dehydration and further weight loss.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

Continue with the current chemotherapy and radiation regimen. Take prednisone and lidocaine swish and swallow as prescribed. Follow up at the next scheduled visit. Call the clinic with any questions or new symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Abnormal lab work - low immunoglobulin A level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Kyle is a patient who was referred by his primary care physician due to a low immunoglobulin A level found during a recent physical examination. The patient reports frequent colds during the winter season that tend to linger, but is unsure if this is more than usual. The patient denies any frequent abdominal infections or diarrhea. The patient has a recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes and has been started on metformin. The patient has no known family history of immune deficiencies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Respiratory: Endorses frequent colds during winter season.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies frequent abdominal infections or diarrhea.
• Endocrine: Type 2 diabetes.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Within normal limits, no fever.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
• Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LABORATORY RESULTS

Low immunoglobulin A level.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low immunoglobulin A level.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient has a low immunoglobulin A level, which is a common immunodeficiency. The patient does not report frequent infections that would be concerning for a more severe immunodeficiency.
   • Additional Testing: Order additional blood work to check other antibody levels.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to monitor for infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control, and to inform any healthcare provider of their iga deficiency if they require blood products in the future.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient has a recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes and is on metformin.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue metformin as prescribed by primary care physician.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage the patient to maintain a healthy diet and monitor blood sugar levels as directed by their primary care physician.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a patient who presents today for an evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient reports that he has been doing a lot of pottery during the pandemic and started to develop elbow pain over the past week. The pain is located on the inside of his right elbow and sometimes radiates down into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The pain has been present for about four days and is rated as a 6/10 in severity. The pain keeps him up at night and affects his ability to perform daily activities. He has tried ibuprofen with minimal relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right elbow pain and limited range of motion.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Positive for pain to palpation at the medial epicondyle of the right elbow. Pain with pronation of the forearm. Pain with resistance against flexion of the right wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right elbow: No fracture or bony abnormality observed.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Lawrence presents today with right elbow pain, consistent with medial epicondylitis.

• Medical Reasoning: The patient's pain is likely due to overuse and potential damage to the tendons that bend the wrist towards the palm, possibly related to his pottery activities.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instructed the patient to rest the elbow, wear a sling while awake, apply ice for 20 minutes three times a day, and avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
• Medical Treatment: Prescribed ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for one week.
• Follow-up: The patient will follow-up in one week for reevaluation.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 1 week.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain, shortness of breath, and swelling in ankles.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

David is a patient who presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, and swelling in ankles. He recently visited the emergency department due to these symptoms. The patient has a history of hypertension and has been prescribed Bumex, Cozaar, and Norvasc. He admits to occasionally missing doses of his medications and has not been strictly following a low-salt diet. He also reports occasional chest pain, which he attributed to heartburn.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain and swelling in ankles.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Former smoker, currently smokes occasionally.

PHYSICAL EXAM

• Blood pressure: 128/72
• Neck: No jugular venous distention.
• Heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Lungs: Clear bilaterally.
• Lower extremities: Trace edema.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Congestive heart failure (CHF)
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's recent echocardiogram showed preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild to moderate mitral regurgitation. The CHF is likely caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily. Consult with nutritionist for dietary advice. Weigh daily and call if weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days.

Hypertension
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a history of hypertension and is currently prescribed Cozaar and Norvasc.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg daily. Encourage consistent medication adherence.

Additional testing
• Order renal artery ultrasound to rule out any underlying issues.

INSTRUCTIONS

1. Continue taking prescribed medications consistently.
2. Consult with a nutritionist for dietary advice.
3. Weigh daily and call if weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days.
4. Obtain a blood pressure cuff and monitor blood pressure at home.
5. Obtain a scale for daily weight monitoring.
6. Follow up with the results of the renal artery ultrasound.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who has been experiencing sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe when it occurs. He has difficulty finding a comfortable position. He reports a burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for the pain without significant relief. He feels nauseated but has not vomited. The patient has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones in his father.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA tenderness: Positive on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen: 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

• Medical Treatment: Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain. Continue alternating with Tylenol. Provide a strainer for urine collection to capture the stone when it passes.
• Additional Testing: Order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
• Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks. If symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to contact the clinic if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy. He presents with a nonhealing foot ulcer on his right foot, which he first noticed about six weeks ago after wearing tight shoes. The ulcer initially presented as a blister but has since become unroofed with thick, soft, mushy skin and yellow drainage. The patient reports a foul smell and has been on antibiotics for six days. He has experienced fever, chills, and worsening pain in the foot. The area around the wound has turned black, and he has developed cramping in his calf muscle. He also reports a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle, which is very hot. The patient has noticed increased coughing and difficulty catching his breath in the last two days.

MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient has a history of diabetes with a well-controlled hemoglobin A1c of 6.7. He has been experiencing elevated blood sugars in the range of 300-400 in the last two weeks, with one spike at 500-600.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Endocrine: Diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.
• Respiratory: Coughing and difficulty catching breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Cramping in the calf muscle and pain in the foot.

PHYSICAL EXAM

• Vitals: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
• Foot exam: Necrotic wound on the right heel, approximately 2x2 cm, with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythema. No bony exposure.
• Vascular exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses, non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.

RESULTS

Right foot X-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer.
- Medical Reasoning: Concern for infection and compromised blood supply to the wound.
- Additional Testing: Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
- Medical Treatment: Perform debridement in the office, obtain a culture, and consider different antibiotic therapy based on culture results. Monitor redness and swelling in the leg.
- Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.

2. Diabetes management.
- Medical Reasoning: Elevated blood sugars and potential impact on wound healing.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current diabetes management and follow up with an endocrinologist.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage the patient to maintain a hemoglobin A1c below 7 and closely monitor blood sugars during treatment.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite and possible Lyme disease.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Richard is a middle-aged male who presents with a tick bite on his right knee. He is unsure of when or where he got the tick bite but spends a lot of time outdoors and went hunting a couple of weeks ago. The tick bite has been present for over a week and is causing burning and discomfort. He denies fever or chills but reports feeling generally unwell and having a headache since the tick bite. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes, which he is managing with lisinopril and metformin, respectively.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses arthritic pain.
• Neurological: Denies dizziness or shortness of breath.
• Skin: Tick bite on the right knee with erythema, edema, and bull's-eye rash.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Blood pressure 122/70, heart rate 67, temperature 98.4°F.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee, full range of motion of the right knee.
• Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Possible Lyme disease:
   • Medical Reasoning: Presence of a tick bite with a bull's-eye rash and general malaise.
   • Additional Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot.
   • Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for three weeks.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is managing hypertension with lisinopril.
   • Additional Testing: Order lipid panel.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg once daily.

3. Diabetes:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is managing diabetes with metformin and reports blood sugars in the 120s.
   • Additional Testing: Order hemoglobin A1c and basic metabolic panel to assess kidney function.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.
